item.title: Integrating IRB (Ruby REPL) into Emacs
item.description:
youtube

From 1961 to Today: The Evolution of Live Coding in Emacs with Ruby (irb) 1961: The first text editors emerge. 1964: The REPL (Read-Eval-Print Loop) is born, revolutionizing interactive programming. 1968: REPL meets the structure editor; code editing becomes interactive and structured. 1977: DEdit splits the structure editor into a separate window, paving the way for modern IDE workflows. 1990s (or earlier): REPLs begin integrating with Emacs through stdin/stdout/stderr; ushering in a new era of developer tooling. Fast forward to today: Emacs can now connect directly to Ruby‚Äôs irb, giving you the best of both worlds: ‚ú® Live, stateful programming: Run and edit your Ruby code interactively while preserving the full execution state; just like in a native irb session. üíæ Full editor capabilities: Save, load, and version-control your code with Git, just like any regular text file. ‚ö° Instant feedback: Modify code in the editor, then evaluate only the changed portion; no restart needed. Keep your program running and evolve it in real time. This powerful workflow blends the timeless elegance of Emacs with the dynamic interactivity of Ruby; bringing decades of programming evolution full circle.
